flu-peak

flu-peak Documentation

Influenza peak prediction with GEV and SIR models.

Installation

pip install -e .

Usage

run_experiment --help

API Reference

Influenza extreme-peak modeling with EVT and SIR.

Data Module

Data loading and synthetic data generation.

Example usage:
>>> import tempfile
>>> from pathlib import Path
>>> df = generate_synthetic_data(n_seasons=1, n_regions=1, seed=42)
>>> len(df) > 0
True
>>> set(df.columns) == {"date", "region", "cases", "tests"}
True
flu_peak.data.generate_synthetic_data(n_seasons=3, n_regions=2, seed=42)[source]

Generate synthetic influenza surveillance data in CDC format.

Parameters:

  • n_seasons (int) – Number of flu seasons to generate

  • n_regions (int) – Number of regions

  • seed (int) – Random seed for reproducibility

Returns:

YEAR, WEEK, REGION, %WEIGHTED ILI

Return type:

DataFrame with CDC-style columns

flu_peak.data.load_flu_data(csv_path)[source]

Load influenza data from CSV in CDC format.

Parameters:

csv_path (Path | str) – Path to CSV file with columns: YEAR, WEEK, REGION, %WEIGHTED ILI

Returns:

DataFrame with validated data

Raises:

ValueError – If required columns are missing

Return type:

DataFrame

Evaluation Module

Evaluation metrics for predictive distributions.

flu_peak.eval.crps(samples, observation)[source]

Continuous Ranked Probability Score.

Parameters:

  • samples (ndarray) – Predictive samples

  • observation (float) – Observed value

Returns:

CRPS (lower is better)

Return type:

float

flu_peak.eval.log_score(samples, observation, bandwidth=None)[source]

Negative log-likelihood score using kernel density estimation.

Parameters:

  • samples (ndarray) – Predictive samples

  • observation (float) – Observed value

  • bandwidth (float | None) – KDE bandwidth (auto if None)

Returns:

Log score (higher is better)

Return type:

float

flu_peak.eval.coverage(lower, upper, observation)[source]

Check if observation falls within prediction interval.

Parameters:

  • lower (float) – Lower bound of interval

  • upper (float) – Upper bound of interval

  • observation (float) – Observed value

Returns:

1.0 if covered, 0.0 otherwise

Return type:

float

flu_peak.eval.brier_score(forecast_prob, observed)[source]

Brier score for binary outcomes.

Parameters:

  • forecast_prob (float) – Forecast probability [0, 1]

  • observed (bool) – Observed outcome

Returns:

Brier score (lower is better)

Return type:

float

flu_peak.eval.pit_histogram(samples_list, observations, bins=10)[source]

Probability Integral Transform histogram for calibration check.

Parameters:

  • samples_list (list[ndarray]) – List of predictive sample arrays (one per observation)

  • observations (ndarray) – Array of observed values

  • bins (int) – Number of histogram bins

Returns:

Tuple of (histogram counts, bin edges)

Return type:

tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

Preprocessing Module

Season extraction and peak detection.

class flu_peak.preprocess.SeasonConfig(start_month=11, start_day=1, end_month=4, end_day=30)[source]

Bases: object

Configuration for flu season boundaries.

Parameters:

  • start_month (int)

  • start_day (int)

  • end_month (int)

  • end_day (int)

start_month: int = 11
start_day: int = 1
end_month: int = 4
end_day: int = 30
class flu_peak.preprocess.SeasonPeak(season, region, peak_cases, peak_week, peak_year)[source]

Bases: object

Peak information for a flu season.

Parameters:

  • season (int)

  • region (str)

  • peak_cases (float)

  • peak_week (int)

  • peak_year (int)

season: int
region: str
peak_cases: float
peak_week: int
peak_year: int
flu_peak.preprocess.extract_season_peaks(df, config=None)[source]

Extract one peak per season per region from CDC format data.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) – DataFrame with columns: YEAR, WEEK, REGION, %WEIGHTED ILI

  • config (SeasonConfig | None) – Season configuration (unused, kept for compatibility)

Returns:

List of SeasonPeak objects

Return type:

list[SeasonPeak]

flu_peak.preprocess.split_train_test(peaks, test_seasons=1)[source]

Split peaks into train and test sets by season.

Parameters:

  • peaks (list[SeasonPeak]) – List of season peaks

  • test_seasons (int) – Number of most recent seasons to hold out

Returns:

Tuple of (train_peaks, test_peaks)

Return type:

tuple[list[SeasonPeak], list[SeasonPeak]]

Models

GEV Model

Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) model for block maxima.

class flu_peak.models.gev.GEVModel(mu, sigma, xi)[source]

Bases: object

Generalized Extreme Value distribution for seasonal peak maxima.

Parameters:

  • mu (float) – Location parameter

  • sigma (float) – Scale parameter

  • xi (float) – Shape parameter (tail index)

mu: float
sigma: float
xi: float
return_level(return_period)[source]

Compute return level for given return period.

Parameters:

return_period (float) – Return period (e.g., 10 for 10-year return level)

Returns:

Return level value

Return type:

float

pdf(x)[source]

Probability density function.

Parameters:

x (ndarray) – Values to evaluate

Returns:

PDF values

Return type:

ndarray

cdf(x)[source]

Cumulative distribution function.

Parameters:

x (ndarray) – Values to evaluate

Returns:

CDF values

Return type:

ndarray

sample(n, seed=None)[source]

Generate samples from the distribution.

Parameters:

  • n (int) – Number of samples

  • seed (int | None) – Random seed

Returns:

Array of samples

Return type:

ndarray

flu_peak.models.gev.fit_gev_to_peaks(peaks, method='mle', use_mom_fallback=True)[source]

Fit GEV to block maxima using maximum likelihood.

Parameters:

  • peaks (ndarray) – Block maxima (e.g., seasonal peaks)

  • method (str) – Fitting method (‘mle’ or ‘mom’)

  • use_mom_fallback (bool) – Use Method of Moments if MLE fails

Returns:

Fitted GEVModel

Raises:

ValueError – If fit fails

Return type:

GEVModel

SIR Model

SIR model for influenza forecasting.

class flu_peak.models.sir.SIRModel(beta, gamma, N)[source]

Bases: object

Deterministic SIR epidemic model.

Parameters:

  • beta (float) – Transmission rate

  • gamma (float) – Recovery rate

  • N (float) – Population size

beta: float
gamma: float
N: float
simulate(t, I0=1, R0=0)[source]

Simulate SIR dynamics.

Parameters:

  • t (ndarray) – Time points

  • I0 (float) – Initial infected

  • R0 (float) – Initial recovered

Returns:

Tuple of (S, I, R) trajectories

Return type:

tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray]

bootstrap_predict(incidence, t, n_bootstrap=100, predict_horizon=10, seed=None)

Bootstrap prediction for SIR model.

Parameters:

  • model (SIRModel) – Fitted SIR model

  • incidence (ndarray) – Observed incidence

  • t (ndarray) – Time points

  • n_bootstrap (int) – Number of bootstrap samples

  • predict_horizon (int) – Steps ahead to predict

  • seed (int | None) – Random seed

Returns:

Array of shape (n_bootstrap, predict_horizon) with predictions

Return type:

ndarray

predict_peak_distribution(incidence, t, n_samples=200, seed=None)

Generate distribution of peak predictions via bootstrap.

Parameters:

  • model (SIRModel) – Fitted SIR model

  • incidence (ndarray) – Observed incidence

  • t (ndarray) – Time points

  • n_samples (int) – Number of bootstrap samples

  • seed (int | None) – Random seed

Returns:

Array of peak predictions

Return type:

ndarray

flu_peak.models.sir.fit_sir_to_incidence(incidence, t, N)[source]

Fit SIR model to incidence data via least squares.

Parameters:

  • incidence (ndarray) – Observed incidence (infected counts)

  • t (ndarray) – Time points

  • N (float) – Population size

Returns:

Fitted SIRModel

Raises:

ValueError – If optimization fails

Return type:

SIRModel

flu_peak.models.sir.bootstrap_predict(model, incidence, t, n_bootstrap=100, predict_horizon=10, seed=None)[source]

Bootstrap prediction for SIR model.

Parameters:

  • model (SIRModel) – Fitted SIR model

  • incidence (ndarray) – Observed incidence

  • t (ndarray) – Time points

  • n_bootstrap (int) – Number of bootstrap samples

  • predict_horizon (int) – Steps ahead to predict

  • seed (int | None) – Random seed

Returns:

Array of shape (n_bootstrap, predict_horizon) with predictions

Return type:

ndarray

flu_peak.models.sir.predict_peak_distribution(model, incidence, t, n_samples=200, seed=None)[source]

Generate distribution of peak predictions via bootstrap.

Parameters:

  • model (SIRModel) – Fitted SIR model

  • incidence (ndarray) – Observed incidence

  • t (ndarray) – Time points

  • n_samples (int) – Number of bootstrap samples

  • seed (int | None) – Random seed

Returns:

Array of peak predictions
